subject: Use new checks in hacking 0.12
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-09 19:31:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/commit/b41e4bf8442abd2a8831c8585c6e5c0f27bb7129', 'message': "Up hacking package to version 0.12

This patch follows suit with neutron's [1] usage of hacking
0.12, by updating neutron-lib to hacking 0.12 and also
removing our definition of check_delayed_string_interpolation.
While we typically wouldn't just remove a public API
in neutron-lib, no consumers have used this check yet
as it's been commented out in the registration factory
and no one uses it directly [3]. Therefore, this patch proposes
we just zap it without deprecation.

In addition, this patch stubs out hacking check consumption
in our usage doc. While we might like consumers just use our
factory and not dig into our tox.ini, the lack of public APIs
in hacking/flake8/pep8 don't provide a way to manipulate the
disabled_by_default attribute of registered checks. So consumers
are stuck with this for now (unless others have ideas).

Finally note that subsequent work hopes to improve our
hacking check process, such as [2].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/394817/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/350723/
[3] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=check_delayed_string_interpolation&i=nope&files=&repos=

Change-Id: Ie9448317855b9cba6092cd0f63b77d26a562a5c9
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-11-14 15:47:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/commit/0a355809bc5103d4c32b88fa8f6ebfdc620f4367', 'message': "Up hacking package to version 0.12

Neutron recently updated their usage of hacking to use
version 0.12 [1] that now contains the hacking check
check_delayed_string_interpolation who's off_by_default
value is initially True (e.g. disabled). This hacking check
is defined in neutron_lib, but hasn't been registered in our
factory and isn't being consumed directly [3].

Given the current limitations of flake8 W/R/T dynamically
changing off_by_default [2] we have the following options
for adopting hacking 0.12:
- We can continue to use our own version of the hacking
check with it's own check code. This only works if we
keep the name of our check function different from that
within hacking; otherwise we have a collision. IMO this
defeats the purpose of using a common hacking project
and obviously duplicates code.
- We can use hacking's version of the check (removing
our version) and enable hacking's check via tox.ini
(see patch set 1 from this change). While this seems
straight forward, IMO it's not the optimal UX experience
as consumers now need to manually inspect our tox.ini
to see what we are 'enabling' from hacking. This may seem
OK, but in the future there may be checks we enable that
we don't want our consumers to pick-up in which case we'll
need to document each one in detail. IMO this is not an optimal
UX and is error prone.
- We can add a flake8 extension to allow off_by_default
to be set at runtime and used. With this approach we can
enable/disable any checks in our factory; including those
from hacking. This is the approach taken herein and IMO
provides the best UX; consumers just use our hacking factory()
and done; nothing else to do.

This patch implements option #3 above by:
- Updating our test-requirements to use hacking 0.12.
- Providing a flake8 extension that rechecks registered
check functions off_by_default values and applies them
to the ignore list (e.g. checks to ignore).
- Removes lib's version of the validator. It was never
included in our factory() nor is it used by anyone
today [3]. This patch proposes we just zap it.
- Enables the hacking check so its registered as enabled.
- Updates our docs to reflect the approach.
- UTs for coverage.

Also note that subsequent work hopes to improve our
hacking check process, such as [4].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/394817/
[2] https://gitlab.com/pycqa/flake8/issues/253
[3] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=check_delayed_string_interpolation&i=nope&files=&repos=
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/350723/

Change-Id: Ie9448317855b9cba6092cd0f63b77d26a562a5c9
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-12-02 22:59:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib/commit/e5983acce0d9d796ae08b4b90434e726b86149cd', 'message': "Use new checks in hacking 0.12

Neutron recently updated their usage of hacking to use
version 0.12 [1] that now contains the hacking check
check_delayed_string_interpolation who's off_by_default
value is initially True (i.e. disabled). This hacking check
is defined in neutron_lib, but hasn't been registered in our
factory and isn't being consumed directly [3].

This patch takes a simple approach to reusing openstack-dev
hacking checks:
- Removes all traces of neutron-lib's version of the check; no one is
using it [3].
- Ups our version of hacking to use hacking 0.12 so we can use the
hacking check in that release.
- Enables the check via enabled extensions in tox.ini as neutron did [1].
- Updates our hacking check usage, noting that adopters should
enable the same extensions we do (via tox.ini).

Also note that while this patch is related to our neutron-lib hacking
check story [4], IMO its independent and can proceed without
waiting on [4] as this patch lays out how we and our adopters reuse
hacking checks from openstack-dev.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/394817/

commit_message:
Use new checks in hacking 0.12

Neutron recently updated their usage of hacking to use
version 0.12 [1] that now contains the hacking check
check_delayed_string_interpolation who's off_by_default
value is initially True (i.e. disabled). This hacking check
is defined in neutron_lib, but hasn't been registered in our
factory and isn't being consumed directly [2].

This patch takes a simple approach to reusing openstack-dev
hacking checks:
- Removes all traces of neutron-lib's version of the check; no one is
using it [2].
- Bumps our version of hacking to use  0.12 so we can use the checks
in that release.
- Enables the check via enabled extensions in tox.ini as neutron did [1].
- Updates our hacking check usage, noting that adopters should
enable the same extensions we do (via tox.ini).

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/394817/
[2] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=check_delayed_string_interpolation&i=nope&files=&repos=

Change-Id: Ie9448317855b9cba6092cd0f63b77d26a562a5c9

subject: Properly distribute extra ceph client keys
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-09 21:13:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-ceph_client/commit/870e6d19ba23ae9257dbbb4c150107034e2b7bbe', 'message': 'Properly distribute extra ceph client keys

When adding extra ceph clusters, client keys are not currently
distributed to hypervisors; This patch ensures that

commit_message:
Properly distribute extra ceph client keys

When adding extra ceph clusters, client keys are not currently
distributed to hypervisors; This patch ensures that
the keys are properly distributed and cleaned up by ansible.

Change-Id: I3eb8fa201f4601565e88e0e68af68e9dfdadc88f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-ceph_client refs/changes/35/409335/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - Properly distrubute client keys to nova hypervisors when extra ceph clusters are being deployed. - Properly remove temporary files used to transfer ceph client keys from the deploy host and hypervisors.

commit_message:
Update $modal to $uibModal

Due to updating XStatic-Angular-Bootstrap to 2.2.0.0,
$modal is deprecated, so we need to use $uibModal.
This patch updates $modal to $uibModal.

Change-Id: I3c0881eb740ad97dfd1b450966e72db99b489b9c
Closes-Bug: #1651054
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum-ui refs/changes/40/412340/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: '$uibModal', $uibModal, magnum, actionResult, gettext, $qExtensions, toast, basePath, resourceType, model function signCertificateModal(html, $uibModal) { return $uibModal.open(localSpec).result; return signCertificateModal(basePath + 'sign-certificate/sign-certificate-modal.html', $uibModal)
deleted_lines: '$modal', $modal, magnum, actionResult, gettext, $qExtensions, toast, basePath, resourceType, model function signCertificateModal(html, $modal) { return $modal.open(localSpec).result; return signCertificateModal(basePath + 'sign-certificate/sign-certificate-modal.html', $modal)

commit_message:
Treat empty body as no body in parse_api_error

If BeautifulSoup is called when html5lib is installed, it will use
its parser when no markup_type is specified. In those cases, an empty
body is included in the parsed output when no dody is included in the
input string.

Change-Id: Ibc7201434b8f09b82cb96f5ffabceba4fbf74de7
Closes-Bug: #1650514

commit_message:
[k8s_fedora_atomic] Enable TLS in Etcd cluster

With this patch following are done:-
- Configure Etcd with TLS support

Configure Following to commuicate with TLS enabled Etcd:-
- Flannel

Etcd also listens at http://127.0.0.1:2379, so on master nodes
etcdctl and kube apiserver can communicate without using
certificates.

if TLS_DISABLED="True" then TLS is not enabled for etcd.

Change-Id: I2147b67c4e346a4415e1f76c19ac68e94cb0a0fa
Partially-Implements: blueprint secure-etcd-cluster-coe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/74/407374/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cert_dir="/srv/kubernetes" protocol="https" if [ "$TLS_DISABLED" = "True" ]; then protocol="http" fiETCD_LISTEN_CLIENT_URLS="$protocol://$myip:2379,http://127.0.0.1:2379" ETCD_LISTEN_PEER_URLS="$protocol://$myip:2380" ETCD_ADVERTISE_CLIENT_URLS="$protocol://$myip:2379,http://127.0.0.1:2379" ETCD_INITIAL_ADVERTISE_PEER_URLS="$protocol://$myip:2380"if [ "$TLS_DISABLED" = "False" ]; then cat >> /etc/etcd/etcd.conf <<EOF ETCD_CA_FILE=$cert_dir/ca.crt ETCD_CERT_FILE=$cert_dir/server.crt ETCD_KEY_FILE=$cert_dir/server.key ETCD_PEER_CA_FILE=$cert_dir/ca.crt ETCD_PEER_CERT_FILE=$cert_dir/server.crt ETCD_PEER_KEY_FILE=$cert_dir/server.key EOF fi

overriding the default requirements files "requirements.txt" and
"quickstart-extras-requirements" and must provide equivalent
requirements.  This is useful for overriding roles or ansible versions.

Change-Id: I7512cc41c8a12474f32069f717c32540051f35c0

commit_message:
make quickstart-extras-requirements.txt a default requirements file

Now that tripleo-quickstart and tripleo-quickstart-extras are both
upstream it makes sense for quickstart-extras to be a default
requirement for the setup via pip.

Change-Id: I7512cc41c8a12474f32069f717c32540051f35c0

deleted_lines: Package: fuel-master-node-services Architecture: all Depends: cobbler, cobbler-web, dbconfig-common, dnsutils, ntp, openstack-clients, postgresql, python-ipaddr, rabbitmq-server, rsync, ${misc:Depends}, Description: Metapackage to install all needed Fuel master node service dependencies OpenStack is a reliable cloud infrastructure. Its mission is to produce the ubiquitous cloud computing platform that will meet the needs of public and private cloud providers regardless of size, by being simple to implement and massively scalable. . Fuel is an open source deployment and management tool for OpenStack. Developed as an OpenStack community effort, it provides an intuitive, GUI-driven experience for deployment and management of OpenStack, related community projects and plug-ins. . Fuel brings consumer-grade simplicity to streamline and accelerate the otherwise time-consuming, often complex, and error-prone process of deploying, testing and maintaining various configuration flavors of OpenStack at scale. Unlike other platform-specific deployment or management utilities, Fuel is an upstream OpenStack project that focuses on automating the deployment and testing of OpenStack and a range of third-party options, so its not compromised by hard bundling or vendor lock-in. . This metapackage contains all services that a fuel master node needs, like a database server, rabbitmq, and so on. Package: fuel-master-node Architecture: all Pre-Depends: fuel-master-node-services, Depends: astute, cobbler, fuel-agent, fuel-misc, fuel-ui, fuel-web-apache, mcollective, nailgun-api, nailgun-assassin, nailgun-reciever, python-fuelclient, ${misc:Depends}, Description: Metapackage to install a Fuel master node server OpenStack is a reliable cloud infrastructure. Its mission is to produce the ubiquitous cloud computing platform that will meet the needs of public and private cloud providers regardless of size, by being simple to implement and massively scalable. . Fuel is an open source deployment and management tool for OpenStack. Developed as an OpenStack community effort, it provides an intuitive, GUI-driven experience for deployment and management of OpenStack, related community projects and plug-ins. . Fuel brings consumer-grade simplicity to streamline and accelerate the otherwise time-consuming, often complex, and error-prone process of deploying, testing and maintaining various configuration flavors of OpenStack at scale. Unlike other platform-specific deployment or management utilities, Fuel is an upstream OpenStack project that focuses on automating the deployment and testing of OpenStack and a range of third-party options, so its not compromised by hard bundling or vendor lock-in. . This metapackage contains all the needed dependencies to install a Fuel master node.

commit_message:
Add Constraints support

Adding constraints support to libraries is slightly more complex than
services as the libraries themselves are listed in upper-constraints.txt
which leads to errors that you can't install a specific version and a
constrained version.

This change adds constraints support by also adding a helper script to
edit the constraints to remove oslo.rootwrap.

Change-Id: Ie14167eced0bba29f7d4e30f815785641c1da6c0

commit_message:
Add a new Hardware Manager for CNA network card

This patch adds a new hardware manager, which will disable the embedded
LLDP agent on Intel CNA network cards in order to allow the gathering of
LLDP data during the inspection process.

Change-Id: I572756ac6a7bf67a7f446738ba9d145e1c1bdc48
Closes-Bug: #1623659

'dda135fb-732d-4742-8e72-df8f3199d244', 'driver_internal_info': {}} CONF.clear_override('disk_wait_attempts') CONF.clear_override('disk_wait_delay') def test_get_clean_steps(self): expected_clean_steps = [ { 'step': 'disable_embedded_lldp_agent_in_x710_card', 'priority': 100, 'interface': 'deploy', 'reboot_requested': False, 'abortable': True, }, { 'step': 'erase_devices', 'priority': 10, 'interface': 'deploy', 'reboot_requested': False, 'abortable': True }, { 'step': 'erase_devices_metadata', 'priority': 99, 'interface': 'deploy', 'reboot_requested': False, 'abortable': True } ] clean_steps = self.hardware.get_clean_steps(self.node, []) self.assertEqual(expected_clean_steps, clean_steps) @mock.patch.object(os, 'listdir', autospec=True) @mock.patch.object(utils, 'execute', autospec=True) def test_detect_x710_card(self, mock_execute, mock_listdir): def mock_return_execute(*args, **kwargs): if 'eth0' in args[0][1]: return '/foo/bar/fake', '' if 'eth1' in args[0][1]: return '/foo/bar/i40e', '' mock_listdir.return_value = ['eth0', 'eth1'] mock_execute.side_effect = mock_return_execute self.assertEqual(True, self.hardware._detect_x710_card()) @mock.patch.object(os, 'listdir', autospec=True) @mock.patch.object(utils, 'execute', autospec=True) def test_detect_x710_card_execute_error(self, mock_execute, mock_listdir): def mock_return_execute(*args, **kwargs): if 'eth0' in args[0][1]: return '/foo/bar/fake', '' if 'eth1' in args[0][1]: return '', 'fake error' mock_listdir.return_value = ['eth0', 'eth1'] mock_execute.side_effect = mock_return_execute self.assertEqual(False, self.hardware._detect_x710_card()) @mock.patch.object(os, 'listdir', autospec=True) @mock.patch.object(utils, 'execute', autospec=True) def test_detect_x710_card_no_i40e_driver(self, mock_execute, mock_listdir): def mock_return_execute(*args, **kwargs): if 'eth0' in args[0][1]: return '/foo/bar/fake', '' if 'eth1' in args[0][1]: return '/foo/bar/fake', '' mock_listdir.return_value = ['eth0', 'eth1'] mock_execute.side_effect = mock_return_execute self.assertEqual(False, self.hardware._detect_x710_card()) @mock.patch.object(hardware, 'LOG', autospec=True) @mock.patch.object(hardware.X710HardwareManager, '_detect_x710_card', autospec=True) def test_evaluate_hardware_support(self, mock_detect_card, mock_log): mock_detect_card.return_value = True expected_support = hardware.HardwareSupport.SERVICE_PROVIDER actual_support = self.hardware.evaluate_hardware_support() self.assertEqual(expected_support, actual_support) mock_log.debug.assert_called_once() @mock.patch.object(hardware, 'LOG', autospec=True) @mock.patch.object(hardware.X710HardwareManager, '_detect_x710_card', autospec=True) def test_evaluate_hardware_support_no_x710_card_detected(self, mock_detect_card, mock_log): mock_detect_card.return_value = False expected_support = hardware.HardwareSupport.NONE actual_support = self.hardware.evaluate_hardware_support() self.assertEqual(expected_support, actual_support) mock_log.debug.assert_called_once() @mock.patch.object(os, 'listdir', autospec=True) def test_disable_embedded_lldp_agent_in_x710_card(self, mock_listdir): mock_listdir.return_value = ['eth0', 'eth1'] write_mock = mock.mock_open() with mock.patch('__builtin__.open', write_mock, create=True): result = self.hardware.disable_embedded_lldp_agent_in_x710_card() write_mock().write.assert_called_with('lldp stop') self.assertEqual(True, result) @mock.patch.object(hardware, 'LOG', autospec=True) @mock.patch.object(os, 'listdir', autospec=True) def test_disable_embedded_lldp_agent_raises_error(self, mock_listdir, mock_log): mock_listdir.side_effect = IOError('fake error') self.assertRaises( IOError, self.hardware.disable_embedded_lldp_agent_in_x710_card) mock_log.warning.assert_called_once()

commit_message:
Remove unneeded 'reserved' filter in cleaning stuck nodes

We just clear all reservations before doing this on conductor start,
so it's unnecessary to filter it again.

Change-Id: Ib13bdb8c63b70b1e3a782b03ea6758745775fbf3

commit_message:
Add support for Ubuntu

Add support to translate package names to what
is in the Ubuntu Archive.

Change-Id: Ie64ecaf1dc7dde9d51e6085215aba56ca3ff3fdd
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pymod2pkg refs/changes/71/408371/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def default_ubuntu_tr(mod): return 'python-' + mod.lower() UBUNTU_PKG_MAP = [ SingleRule('Babel', 'python-babel'), SingleRule('PuLP', 'python-pulp'), SingleRule('Django', 'python-django'), SingleRule('django_openstack_auth', 'python-openstack-auth'), SingleRule('Flask', 'python-flask'), SingleRule('glance_store', 'python-glance-store'), SingleRule('GitPython', 'python-git'), SingleRule('pyScss', 'python-pyscss'), SingleRule('Mako', 'python-mako'), SingleRule('Pillow', 'python-pillow'), SingleRule('PrettyTable', 'python-prettytable'), SingleRule('PyECLib', 'python-pyeclib'), SingleRule('PyMySQL', 'python-mysql'), SingleRule('pyOpenSSL', 'python-openssl'), SingleRule('PyYAML', 'python-yaml'), SingleRule('Routes', 'python-routes'), SingleRule('SQLAlchemy', 'python-sqlalchemy'), SingleRule('sqlalchemy-migrate', 'python-migrate'), SingleRule('suds-jarko', 'python-suds'), SingleRule('WebOb', 'python-webob'), SingleRule('WebTest', 'python-webtest'), # Openstack services MultiRule( # keep lists in alphabetic order mods=['ceilometer', 'cinder', 'designate', 'glance', 'heat', 'ironic', 'keystone', 'manila', 'mistral', 'neutron', 'nova', 'rally', 'sahara', 'swift', 'tuskar', 'zaqar'], pkgfun=default_ubuntu_tr), # Openstack clients MultiRule( mods=['python-%sclient' % c for c in ( 'barbican', 'ceilometer', 'cinder', 'cloudkitty', 'congress', 'designate', 'fuel', 'heat', 'glance', 'ironic', 'karbor', 'keystone', 'magnum', 'manila', 'mistral', 'monasca', 'murano', 'neutron', 'nova', 'openstack', 'sahara', 'senlin', 'swift', 'trove', 'zaqar')], pkgfun=lambda x: x), ] if dist.lower().find('ubuntu') != -1: return UBUNTU_PKG_MAP if dist.lower().find('ubuntu') != -1: return default_ubuntu_tr

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-12-06 09:43:53.000000000', 'files': ['renderspec/__init__.py', 'tests.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/renderspec/commit/dce9ca710de26dc8c1c41e0767d7f96a4eb0ef97', 'message': 'Check version length in py2rpmversion() for Fedora

 * in case of python version like 10.0.0.0b1 resulting version
   should be 10.0.0 instead of 10.0.0.0

commit_message:
Check version length in py2rpmversion() for Fedora

 * in case of python version like 10.0.0.0b1 resulting version
   should be 10.0.0 instead of 10.0.0.0
 * reference - http://docs.openstack.org/developer/pbr/semver.html

Change-Id: Ia823b046b14e5d50b3db9d8dbe561df0018c1b87

commit_message:
Nova Flavor Resource Update

Add ability to associate private flavors with multiple tenants.
Also updated 'test_flavor' file to reflect changes and test
functionality.

Change-Id: I841460b936ae52b3a91981029b42212ae484c3e4
Implements: blueprint nova-flavor-resource

added_lines: TENANTS, ID, NAME, RAM, VCPUS, DISK, SWAP, 'tenants', 'flavorid', 'name', 'ram', 'vcpus', 'disk', 'swap', TENANTS: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.LIST, _('List of tenants.'), update_allowed=True, default=None ), tenants = args.pop(self.TENANTS) if tenants is None: raise Exception( "if IS_PUBLIC is false, tenant property required") else: for tenant in tenants: # grant access only to the active project(private flavor) self.client().flavor_access.add_tenant_access(flavor, tenant) """Update tenant access list.""" if self.TENANTS in prop_diff: kwargs = {'flavor': self.resource_id} old_tenants = [x.tenant_id for x in self.client(). flavor_access.list(**kwargs)] or [] new_tenants = prop_diff.get(self.TENANTS) or [] tenants_to_remove = list(set(old_tenants) - set(new_tenants)) tenants_to_add = list(set(new_tenants) - set(old_tenants)) if tenants_to_remove or tenants_to_add: flavor = self.client().flavors.get(self.resource_id) for _tenant in tenants_to_remove: self.client().flavor_access.remove_tenant_access(flavor, _tenant) for _tenant in tenants_to_add: self.client().flavor_access.add_tenant_access(flavor, _tenant)

revisions:

The repo name for the os_ironic role was setup incorrectly and has since

Change-Id: Ib649165720ceafb0a5129ffbb1af7f3f842349b9
'}]
commit_message:
Fix openstack-ansible-ironic to openstack-ansible-os_ironic

The repo name for the os_ironic role was setup incorrectly and has since
been changed, but the role itself has some left over references to the
old role name - this patch fixes those.

Change-Id: Ib649165720ceafb0a5129ffbb1af7f3f842349b9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_ironic refs/changes/68/412468/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Defaults file for openstack-ansible-os_ironic

subject: Typo in bank-plugin-lease.rst
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/karbor refs/changes/60/403560/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Bank Plugin is a component of karbor (an openstack project working as a service for data protection), which is responsible for execute CRUD actions in Bank. The bank is a backend (such as swift) which is used to store the metadata/data of protection plan. Here, we take swift as an bank implementation example. ************ Karbor will create a checkpoint when protecting a protection plan. This checkpoint is maintained with status, which is a enum type: protecting, available, restoring, deleted, etc. The status is used for karbor API layer to control access to one checkpoint from users. With the 'protecting' status, there're two cases which we can't tell the difference: 1. The protection service is working and those 'protecting' protection plan are being executed; 2. When the Protection Service crashes, those 'protecting' protection plan are actually zombie ones, and those checkpoints are zombie ones too; In the second case, we need a garbage collection component (GC) to cleanup those zombie checkpoints. In order to tell whether the checkpoint is a zombie or not, we introduce a lease mechanism based on bank plugin. Here, we take swift as an example. The lease is stored as an object in swift with the characteristics of auto-deleted. The owner of one checkpoint will periodically refresh the expire time of the lease object key. When the protection service crashes, the leases of bank plugins will be auto-deleted by the swift-object-expirer(one service of swift). When GC comes to check whether one checkpoint is a zombie to be collected, GC will first get the owner of the checkpoint. Then it will check whether the lease of the owner exists. If the lease exists, those 'protecting' checkpoints can not be deleted by the GC; otherwise the GC will cleanup them.=========== To avoid flood to bank server, we don't keep one lease for per checkpoint. Instead, we keep one lease per checkpoint owner. So the granularity of lease is per bank plugin instance. When one protection service instance gets initialized, each bank plugin instance will get initialized as well. Each bank plugin will start to maintain its own leases with its corresponding bank server. Here, every bank plugin will play a role as lease client while the bank server (swift cluster) plays as the lease server.=========Each bank plugin (lease client) will use this function to acquire a lease from bank server (lease server). For swift specifically, it will create a lease object in swift container and set an expire_window for this lease. The expire_window represents the validity of this lease from creation (or latest-renew) until being auto-deleted by swift server. The value of expire_window should be configurable. We use owner_id to identify one instance of bank plugin. The owner_id is a uuid created when bank plugin instance is initiated, say, generated from sha256 with parameter as hostname and the timestamp instance initiated. The key of lease object stored in swift looks like this: /account/leases/owner_id.- put_object: use swift-client to create a lease object in swift, and set 'X-Delete-After' as: expire_window - set_expire_time in memory in lease client side: set the expire_time as: now+expired_time-----------The renew_window represents the period with which the lease client will refresh lease frequently. This renew_window is configurable as well, where renew_window < expire_window. If lease client succeeds to renew lease, this lease has a new expire_window in lease server from now on. Then the lease client side will update the expire_time in memory with value as: expire_time = now + expired_window. If lease client fails to renew, this lease object keeps the old expire_window in lease server side. The lease client won't update its expire_time in memory. - post_object: use swift-client to reset the 'X-Delete-After' header as: expired_window - update_expire_time: if post_object succeeds, update expire_time as: now+expired_window; otherwise, don't refresh the expire_time.This function is used by the checkpoint owner to check whether there is enough time to execute an update operation to one checkpoint (or anything else guarded by the lease) before the lease expiring. We use validity_window to represent the time window inside which an update operation to a checkpoint should complete. This window is configurable and should be estimated by admin. This function will check if validity_window <= expire_time - now. If it's true, this function will return true and thus allow update operation to go ahead; otherwise, this function will return false and the update operation will abort. Although the lease may haven't expired when validity_window <= expire_time - now, there might not be enough time to finish the update operation. If we allow the update operation to go ahead under this situation, there is a risk that while the operation is still on-going, the lease has been recycled by lease server during this period.This function is used by GC to check whether the lease object exists or not in lease server side. Specifically for checkpoints, GC will scan all checkpoints in 'protecting' status. It will first get the owner of a checkpoint through its index, and then check the existence of the lease object in lease server. If the lease object doesn't exist, it will take this checkpoint as zombie and go ahead to recycle it. Otherwise, it will skip this checkpoint and leave it there.- represents the period with which lease client will renew the lease in background.------------- - represents how long this lease from creation or latest-renew to expire in lease server side. - Note: expired_window > renew_window. To make renew mechanism more robust, we recommend to set expired_window = N*renew_window. With this setting, we allow (N-1) times failure to renew lease to tolerate unstable network case or IO scheduling issue;- an optional configuration; The default value it set according to the renew_window, validity_window <= renew_window - the window estimated by admin, how long one update operation will take at most. The constraint here should be: validity_window < expire_window. - Note: Same background as renew_window setting, to allow (N-1) times failure of renew lease, we recommend to set validity_window <= renew_window.
deleted_lines: Bank Plugin is a component of karbor (an openstack project working as a service for data protection), which is responsible for execute CRUD actions in Bank. The bank is a backend (such as swift) which is used to store the metadata/data of protection plan. Here, we take swift as an bank implementation example. ************** Smuag will create a checkpoint when protecting a protection plan. This checkpoint is maintained with status, which is a enum type: protecting, available, restoring, deleted, etc. The status is used for karbor API layer to control access to one checkpoint from users. With the 'protecting' status, there're two cases which we can't tell the difference: 1. The protection service is working and those 'protecting' protection plan are being executed; 2. When the Protection Service crashes, those 'protecting' protection plan are actually zombie ones, and those checkpoints are zombie ones too; In the second case, we need a garbage collection component (GC) to cleanup those zombie checkpoints. In order to tell whether the checkpoint is a zombie or not, we introduce a lease mechanism based on bank plugin. Here, we take swift as an example. The lease is stored as an object in swift with the characteristics of auto-deleted. The owner of one checkpoint will periodically refresh the expire time of the lease object key. When the protection service crashes, the leases of bank plugins will be auto-deleted by the swift-object-expirer(one service of swift). When GC comes to check whether one checkpoint is a zombie to be collected, GC will first get the owner of the checkpoint. Then it will check whether the lease of the owner exists. If the lease exists, those 'protecting' checkpoints can not be deleted by the GC; otherwise the GC will cleanup them.================= To avoid flood to bank server, we don't keep one lease for per checkpoint. Instead, we keep one lease per checkpoint owner. So the granularity of lease is per bank plugin instance. When one protection service instance gets initialized, each bank plugin instance will get initialized as well. Each bank plugin will start to maintain its own leases with its corresponding bank server. Here, every bank plugin will play a role as lease client while the bank server (swift cluster) plays as the lease server.===============Each bank plugin (lease client) will use this function to acquire a lease from bank server (lease server). For swift specifically, it will create a lease object in swift container and set an expire_window for this lease. The expire_window represents the validity of this lease from creation(or latest-renew) until being auto-deleted by swift server. The value of expire_window should be configurable. We use owner_id to identify one instance of bank plugin. The owner_id is a uuid created when bank plugin instance is initiated, say, generated from sha256 with parameter as hostname and the timestamp instance initiated. The key of lease object stored in swift looks like this: /account/leases/owner_id.- put_object: use swift-client to create a lease object in swift, and set 'X-Delete-After' as: expire_window - set_expire_time in memory in lease client side: set the expire_time as: now+expired_time-----------------The renew_window represents the period with which the lease client will refresh lease frequently. This renew_window is configurable as well, where renew_window < expire_window. If lease client succeeds to renew lease, this lease has a new expire_window in lease server from now on. Then the lease client side will update the expire_time in memory with value as: expire_time = now + expired_window. If lease client fails to renew, this lease object keeps the old expire_window in lease server side. The lease client won't update its expire_time in memory. - post_object: use swift-client to reset the 'X-Delete-After' header as: expired_window - update_expire_time: if post_object succeeds, update expire_time as: now+expired_window; otherwise, don't refresh the expire_time.This function is used by the checkpoint owner to check whether there is enough time to execute an update operation to one checkpoint (or anything else guarded by the lease) before the lease expiring. We use validity_window to represent the time window inside which an update operation to a checkpoint should complete. This window is configurable and should be estimated by admin. This function will check if validity_window <= expire_time - now. If it's true, this function will return true and thus allow update operation to go ahead; otherwise, this function will return false and the update operation will abort. Although the lease may haven't expired when validity_window <= expire_time - now, there might not be enough time to finish the update operation. If we allow the update operation to go ahead under this situation, there is a risk that while the operation is still on-going, the lease has been recycled by lease server during this period.This function is used by GC to check whether the lease object exists or not in lease server side. Specifically for checkpoints, GC will scan all checkpoints in 'protecting' status. It will first get the owner of a checkpoint through its index, and then check the existence of the lease object in lease server. If the lease object doesn't exist, it will take this checkpoint as zombie and go ahead to recycle it. Otherwise, it will skip this checkpoint and leave it there.- represents the period with which lease client will renew the lease in background.-------------- - represents how long this lease from creation or latest-renew to expire in lease server side. - Note: expired_window > renew_window. To make renew mechanism more robust, we recommend to set expired_window = N*renew_window. With this setting, we allow (N-1) times failure to renew lease to tolerate unstable network case or IO scheduling issue;- an optional configuration; The default value it set according to the renew_window, validity_window <= renew_window - the window estimated by admin, how long one update operation will take at most. The constraint here should be: validity_window < expire_window. - Note: Same background as renew_window setting, to allow (N-1) times failure of renew lease, we recommend to set validity_window <= renew_window.

Default=None.') @utils.arg('--end_date', metavar='<end_date>', default=None, help='Filters results by a end_date("%Y-%m-%d"). added_lines: def test_checkpoint_for_server_attached_volume(self): """Test checkpoint for server which has attached some volumes""" volume = self.store(objects.Volume()) volume.create(1) server = self.store(objects.Server()) server.create() server.attach_volume(volume.id) plan0 = self.store(objects.Plan()) plan0.create(self.provider_id, [server, ]) checkpoints = self.karbor_client.checkpoints.list(self.provider_id) before_checkpoints_num = len(checkpoints) backups = self.cinder_client.backups.list() before_backups_num = len(backups) checkpoint = self.store(objects.Checkpoint()) checkpoint.create(self.provider_id, plan0.id, timeout=900) checkpoints = self.karbor_client.checkpoints.list(self.provider_id) after_checkpoints_num = len(checkpoints) self.assertEqual(1, after_checkpoints_num - before_checkpoints_num) backups = self.cinder_client.backups.list() after_backups_num = len(backups) self.assertEqual(1, after_backups_num - before_backups_num) plan1 = self.store(objects.Plan()) plan1.create(self.provider_id, [server, volume]) checkpoints = self.karbor_client.checkpoints.list(self.provider_id) before_checkpoints_num = len(checkpoints) backups = self.cinder_client.backups.list() before_backups_num = len(backups) checkpoint = self.store(objects.Checkpoint()) checkpoint.create(self.provider_id, plan1.id, timeout=720) checkpoints = self.karbor_client.checkpoints.list(self.provider_id) after_checkpoints_num = len(checkpoints) self.assertEqual(1, after_checkpoints_num - before_checkpoints_num) backups = self.cinder_client.backups.list() after_backups_num = len(backups) self.assertEqual(1, after_backups_num - before_backups_num) server.detach_volume(volume.id)

subject: Remove pointless doc-publisher-site parameter
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-19 14:56:27.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/jobs/infra-publish-jobs.yaml', 'jenkins/jobs/openstack-publish-jobs.yaml', 'jenkins/jobs/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/a584363a4e57aab4a69b8300dc3313dac83d9f49', 'message': "Remove pointless doc-publisher-site parameter

Across the entirety of our job config corpus, we only ever set the
doc-publisher-site parameter to docs.openstack.org. Instead just set
it directly in the publishers where it's needed and reduce
unwarranted confusion for people writing job configs.

Change-Id: I87a17ee7de618361f12a025d23629b7d5d711810
"}]
commit_message:
Remove pointless doc-publisher-site parameter

Across the entirety of our job config corpus, we only ever set the
doc-publisher-site parameter to docs.openstack.org. Instead just set
it directly in the publishers where it's needed and reduce
unwarranted confusion for people writing job configs.

Change-Id: I87a17ee7de618361f12a025d23629b7d5d711810

commit_message:
Remove pointless tarball-site parameter

Across the entirety of our job config corpus, we only ever set the
tarball-site parameter to tarballs.openstack.org. Instead just set
it directly in the publishers where it's needed and reduce
unwarranted confusion for people writing job configs. This also
allows us to get rid of the parameterized sites in the tarball,
wheel and war publishers.

Change-Id: I31109f41177b8c07177d7ed8ef16cbfd135131ef

Change-Id: Ie954a679674b4795079b539ebc8d4d2dcbd7dacc

commit_message:
Always add the service role to service users

When creating a service user we allow the user to be created with a
different role. Currently in auth_token middleware we want to check that
the service token is specified with the service role so we should always
add the service role and optionally add additional roles.

Change-Id: Ie954a679674b4795079b539ebc8d4d2dcbd7dacc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/39/410039/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # We always add the service role, other roles are also allowed to be added as historically get_or_add_user_project_role service "$1" "$SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME" "$SERVICE_DOMAIN_NAME" "$SERVICE_DOMAIN_NAME" if [[ -n "$2" ]]; then get_or_add_user_project_role "$2" "$1" "$SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME" "$SERVICE_DOMAIN_NAME" "$SERVICE_DOMAIN_NAME" fi
deleted_lines: # The role defaults to the service role. It is allowed to be provided as optional as historically local role=${2:-service} get_or_add_user_project_role "$role" "$1" "$SERVICE_PROJECT_NAME" "$SERVICE_DOMAIN_NAME" "$SERVICE_DOMAIN_NAME"

commit_message:
Remove dead begin/end code from InstanceUsageAuditLogController

The begin and end kwargs in the _get_audit_task_logs method are
never used, so this change removes them. This was most likely
and oversight when refactoring this code originally from the following
changes:

2fdd73816c56b578a65466db4e5a86b9b191e1c1

aad7743f42e559aefde37bb44622986df4e2ae98

Change-Id: Ie59821d133a33ef9069d2c97e8b4fa60025d1825

added_lines: task_log = self._get_audit_task_logs(context, before=before_date) def _get_audit_task_logs(self, context, before=None): :param context: Nova request context. begin, end = utils.last_completed_audit_period(before=before)
deleted_lines: task_log = self._get_audit_task_logs(context, before=before_date) def _get_audit_task_logs(self, context, begin=None, end=None, before=None): :param begin: datetime beginning of audit period to get logs for, Defaults to the beginning of the most recently completed audit period prior to the 'before' date. :param end: datetime ending of audit period to get logs for, Defaults to the ending of the most recently completed audit period prior to the 'before' date. defbegin, defend = utils.last_completed_audit_period(before=before) if begin is None: begin = defbegin if end is None: end = defend

commit_message:
Fully support MAC address change on CreateEndpoint

An optional MAC address can be provided by libnetwork when calling
NetworkDriver.CreateEndpoint. Whenever present, such
MAC address is only taken into account and actually set on new Neutron
port creates, while ignored on Neutron port updates.

This patch adds support for updating the provided MAC address in
_update_port, similarly to _create_port, and makes their coding style
more consistent.

Change-Id: Ic81aca8fffceadecc05849bbe84e9b859d97ee4f
Signed-off-by: Marco Chiappero <marco.chiappero@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kuryr-libnetwork refs/changes/36/406636/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: response_port = app.neutron.create_port({'port': port}) return response_port['port'] def _update_port(port, endpoint_id, interface_mac): port_updates = { 'name': utils.get_neutron_port_name(endpoint_id), 'device_owner': lib_const.DEVICE_OWNER, 'device_id': endpoint_id } if interface_mac: port_updates['mac_address'] = interface_mac {'port': port_updates}) response_port = _update_port(port, endpoint_id, interface_mac)
deleted_lines: rcvd_port = app.neutron.create_port({'port': port}) return rcvd_port['port'] def _update_port(port, endpoint_id): port['name'] = utils.get_neutron_port_name(endpoint_id) {'port': { 'name': port['name'], 'device_owner': lib_const.DEVICE_OWNER, 'device_id': endpoint_id}}) response_port = _update_port(port, endpoint_id)

commit_message:
Add a type for the ControlVirtualIP resource

This patch adds a new type called:
  OS::TripleO::Network::Ports::ControlPlaneVipPort

This defaults to a normal OS::Neutron::Port object but can
be mocked out for some implementations like when installing
the undercloud where neutron doesn't exist.

Change-Id: Iebf2428432a98a9d789b206ce973599adbc0af8f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/45/409545/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Skip tempest tests if ironic isn't available

This commit makes ironic tempest tests be skipped if ironic is disabled
within tempest.conf

This would allow to disable *only* the ironic tempest tests in an
environment where multiple projects containing in-tree plugins are
installed. As the tempest in-tree plugins are discovered using their
project's setup.cfg entry points, a user wanting to run tempest and not
using virtualenvs would be able to disable the execution. This covers as
well the the usescase where tempest is installed from an OS package.

Change-Id: I1ffcfa71fbc401d9eed03f53e6ad3792177e9ca8

commit_message:
Collect logs at the end of gate

Collecting more logs will be helpful for use to debug the gate.

Closes-Bug: #1650552
Change-Id: I5e243c4e5075215cbed57b65655c99f2ddcadaaf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/03/411403/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set -o errexit set -o xtrace function collect_logs { set +o errexit mkdir -p logs # No matter what, archive logs and config files if which journalctl ; then # the journal gives us syslog() and kernel output, so is like # a concatenation of the above. sudo journalctl --no-pager | sudo tee logs/syslog.txt > /dev/null sudo journalctl --no-pager -u docker.service | sudo tee logs/docker.log > /dev/null else # assume rsyslog sudo cp /var/log/syslog logs/syslog.txt sudo cp /var/log/kern.log logs/kern_log.txt sudo cp /var/log/upstart/docker.log logs/docker.log fi if [[ -d /var/lib/docker/volumes/kolla_logs/_data ]]; then sudo cp -r /var/lib/docker/volumes/kolla_logs/_data logs/kolla_logs fi # sudo config sudo cp -r /etc/sudoers.d logs/ sudo cp /etc/sudoers logs/sudoers.txt df -h | sudo tee logs/df.txt > /dev/null if [ `command -v dpkg` ]; then dpkg -l | sudo tee logs/dpkg-l.txt > /dev/null fi if [ `command -v rpm` ]; then rpm -qa | sudo tee logs/rpm-qa.txt > /dev/null fi # final memory usage and process list ps -eo user,pid,ppid,lwp,%cpu,%mem,size,rss,cmd > logs/ps.txt sudo cp -r /etc/kolla logs/kolla_configs # fix the permissions for logs folder sudo chmod -R 777 logs # Compress all text logs sudo find logs -iname '*.txt' -execdir gzip -9 {} \+ sudo find logs -iname '*.dat' -execdir gzip -9 {} \+ sudo find logs -iname '*.conf' -execdir gzip -9 {} \+ set -o errexit } trap collect_logs EXIT

commit_message:
Add support for setting router gateway

This patch adds the support to set the gateway information
for a router.

Implements: blueprint neutron-client-advanced-router
Partially-Implements: blueprint network-commands-options
Change-Id: Ifb5a4d1965cd7e75c0c8cf2cfb677e0628b699dc
Depends-On: I2bda0dd40afd64b6cecca5f64ef2326bda4fac92
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/73/357973/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: router gateway set ------------------ Set the gateway information for router .. program:: router gateway set .. code:: bash os router gateway set [--project <project> [--project-domain <project-domain>]] [--enable-snat|--disable-snat] [--fixed-ip subnet=<subnet>,ip-address=<ip-address>] <router> <network> .. option:: --project <project> Owner's project (name or ID) .. option:: --project-domain <project-domain> Domain the project belongs to (name or ID). This can be used in case collisions between project names exist. .. option:: --enable-snat Enable Source NAT .. option:: --disable-snat Disable Source NAT .. option:: --fixed-ip subnet=<subnet>,ip-address=<ip-address> Desired IP and/or subnet (name or ID) on external network: subnet=<subnet>,ip-address=<ip-address> (repeat option to set multiple fixed IP addresses) .. _router_gateway_set: .. describe:: <router> Router on which gateway will be set (name or ID) .. describe:: <network> External Network of the gateway (name or ID)

commit_message:
Add option to set DNS name servers on the undercloud

This adds the ability to set the DNS for the undercloud. This
introduces the undercloud_undercloud_nameservers variable which can
be set in in two ways:

* Setting it to a string will just set the configuration to that
  given value as-is.
* Setting it to a list of DNS servers will join the list with ',' as
  separators; This is done to fit with the oslo.config's ListOpt
  format.

As expected, not setting this value will just leave the configuration
option blank.

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I98fc4baca0b935cbf8ee19b71921769ea041c164
Depends-On: I2b8a3f64dc1958f00b0471b68ba8283da76a4e7b

added_lines: Login to instance (from Linux) .. note:: The `ip` command is available only on Linux. Using `ip netns` provides your environment a copy of the network stack, with its own routes, firewall rules, and network devices, for better troubleshooting. the quotes. For any other operating system, use SSH keys. Login to instance with a public IP address (from Mac) .. code-block:: console $ ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub cloud-user@128.107.37.150

[admin-guide] Update cli commands

Replace nova cli commands with openstack cli commands

Change-Id: I08d3cb4f65318dea8b7326460eec10038bf8cb97

commit_message:
VirtualBMC support for tripleo-quickstart

This patch is replacing the usage of the pxe_ssh driver in Ironic in
favor of pxe_ipmitool + VirtualBMC*. The main reason for this patch is
because the pxe_ssh driver is already marked as unsupported and will be
removed from Ironic upstream at the end of the Ocata release.

Older releases: Liberty, Mitaka and Newton will continue to rely on the
pxe_ssh driver.

* VirtualBMC is a proxy that converts IPMI commands to libvirt calls

Partial-Bug: #1645733
Change-Id: Iaaa9fc1fd593cbce045456f4341c461a8eea82ad

commit_message:
Sync debian-sysmaint password

For mysql under debian we should have configured mysql-user debian-sys-maint
for proper logrotate operation, etc. Right now we have desynchronization
between password stored in debian.cnf and in mysql database.

Closes-Bug: 1650283
Change-Id: I55d0a7c44980d7ebbd9606c08bb0a744f265feec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/34/396234/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $deb_sysmaint_password = pick($mysql_hash['deb_sysmaint_password'], sysmaint) deb_sysmaint_password => $deb_sysmaint_password, mysql_user { 'debian-sys-maint@localhost': ensure => 'present', password_hash => mysql_password($deb_sysmaint_password), provider => 'mysql', require => File['/root/.my.cnf'], } mysql_grant { 'debian-sys-maint@localhost/*.*': ensure => 'present', options => ['GRANT'], privileges => ['ALL'], table => '*.*', user => 'debian-sys-maint@localhost', }

subject: Update MTU on existing devices
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-01 17:03:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/bd77505366882f15bfbf9f1f732ed7b78eaa8663', 'message': "ovs: make OVS interface_driver to attempt plug() for existing devices

If for example a device changed MTU in between agent restarts, then we'd
like to see the MTU updated on the port, but it does not happen.

Change-Id: I3c6d6cb55c5808facec38f87114c2ddf548f05f1
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-12-13 17:19:40.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a60299c0d965f4c7abf72c03ad6eace120bbeafb', 'message': 'Update MTU on existing devices

This patch makes OVS and Linuxbridge interface drivers to set MTU on
plug() attempt if the device already exists. This helps when network MTU
changes (which happens after some configuration file changes).

This will allow to update MTU values on agent restart, without the need
to bind all ports to new nodes, that would involve migrating agents. It
will also help in case when you have no other nodes to migrate to (in
single node mode).

Both OVS and Linuxbridge interface drivers are updated. IVS driver
instead warns about the missing feature, and does it just once per
process. An interested party is welcome to propose a patch for the
driver that would make it update MTU on existing ports.

NeutronLibImpact
The change adds a new abstract method to base interface driver class,
which will break all 3party interface drivers. The easiest way to fix
such a breakage is proposing an empty implementation for set_mtu.

Related: If438e4816b425e6c5021a55567dcaaa77d1fffff
Related: If09eda334cddc74910dda7a4fb498b7987714be3
Change-Id: I3c6d6cb55c5808facec38f87114c2ddf548f05f1
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-12-13 17:29:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/9bf7400ed6020429ddbd52801d789519b61571fd', 'message': 'Update MTU on existing devices

This patch makes OVS and Linuxbridge interface drivers to set MTU on
plug() attempt if the device already exists. This helps when network MTU
changes (which happens after some configuration file changes).

This will allow to update MTU values on agent restart, without the need
to bind all ports to new nodes, that would involve migrating agents. It
will also help in case when you have no other nodes to migrate to (in
single node mode).

Both OVS and Linuxbridge interface drivers are updated. IVS driver
instead warns about the missing feature, and does it just once per
process. An interested party is welcome to propose a patch for the
driver that would make it update MTU on existing ports.

NeutronLibImpact
The change adds a new abstract method to base interface driver class,
which will break all 3party interface drivers. The easiest way to fix
such a breakage is proposing an empty implementation for set_mtu.

Related: If09eda334cddc74910dda7a4fb498b7987714be3
Change-Id: I3c6d6cb55c5808facec38f87114c2ddf548f05f1

commit_message:
Update MTU on existing devices

This patch makes OVS and Linuxbridge interface drivers to set MTU on
plug() attempt if the device already exists. This helps when network MTU
changes (which happens after some configuration file changes).

This will allow to update MTU values on agent restart, without the need
to bind all ports to new nodes, that would involve migrating agents. It
will also help in case when you have no other nodes to migrate to (in
single node mode).

Both OVS and Linuxbridge interface drivers are updated.

Other drivers (in-tree IVS as well as 3party drivers) will use the
default set_mtu implementation, that only warns about the missing
feature (once per process startup).

DocImpact suggest to restart agents after MTU config changes instead of
          rewiring router/DHCP ports.

Related: If438e4816b425e6c5021a55567dcaaa77d1fffff
Related: If09eda334cddc74910dda7a4fb498b7987714be3
Closes-Bug: #1649845
Change-Id: I3c6d6cb55c5808facec38f87114c2ddf548f05f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/32/405532/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Configuration templates updated

We need to update configuration templates with services definition and
appropriate "notify" parameters since new OpenStack configuration format
has been introduced.

commit_message:
Remove /usr/bin/install from allowed commands

This essentially allows the user to copy any files and set any
ownership on any files. Can be used to do anything on the system and
all users in 'kolla' group have access to it.

Change-Id: I9d6cd2b4ca40cb536484fa45e80692105b5fa2a4
(cherry picked from commit 73681e760723e899252bd814745ea891c757b7c6)

commit_message:
Ensure random object unique constraints aren't violated

The unit test framework for objects generates random values
for the objects it creates. We need to pay attention to
previously generated values to avoid using the same value
for data models that have unique constrains.

Closes-Bug: #1650615
Change-Id: I0c54b0d82b8c15f2740cce5a850c8fa50acba536
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/97/411897/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._unique_tracker = collections.defaultdict(set) for keys in obj_cls.unique_keys: keytup = tuple(keys) unique_values = tuple(fields[k] for k in keytup) if unique_values in self._unique_tracker[keytup]: # if you get a recursion depth error here, it means # your random generator didn't generate unique values return self.get_random_object_fields(obj_cls) self._unique_tracker[keytup].add(unique_values)

commit_message:
ppc64el: fix for grub2 missing package

Then pkg-mapping missing for the ppc64el ubuntu
image for grub2.

This fix adds the package mapping explicitly so
that name_map is populated with the 'ieee1275'
package name for grub2 on ubuntu ppc64el.

Change-Id: Id2b0f63a7015f883070fd59b79fd96a1c024858a
Closes-Bug: #1624021

commit_message:
Remove grenade config workaround

Starting with Idede322190d57491d4f7e18090aa8c29b5b87353 base and target
releases has the same tempest config file. This patch drops setting
fixed_network_name in target tempest.conf workaround.

Change-Id: I661ace60bf9b4817f73aaccda9c18e24adfc4e56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/81/411781/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # NOTE(vsaienko) fixed_network_name tempest config option setting logic was changed in # https://review.openstack.org/374311/ and until it is not reverted or # https://review.openstack.org/380006 is merged we need to set fixed_network_name explicitly. TEMPEST_CONFIG="$TARGET_RELEASE_DIR/tempest/etc/tempest.conf" iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG compute fixed_network_name $PRIVATE_NETWORK_NAME

commit_message:
Switch Ubuntu to overlay2 docker driver

With 4.4 kernel we can use the improved overlay2 driver instead of
btrfs for significantly better performance when creating layers.

Change-Id: I3b0dfd6db5298dfb34ec160eed910ca76feeb423

commit_message:
Run `yum update -y` before Puppet run

This patch run `yum update -y` right before running os-refresh-config
(Puppet).

1) Running `yum` from an Exec in Puppet is a bad idea because Puppet has
no idea which packages resources are touched, so we're loosing the
orchestration control.

2) We need to ensure that `yum update -y` runs before any attempt to
deploy OpenStack services, so we have latest packages from RDO and
CentOS.

Change-Id: Ifbbbdbf1f0c569791abc712913c7e0f6bbe533d9
Closes-Bug: #1650374

commit_message:
Enable ml2 rally jobs

Add options to the gate_hook.sh script to spawn rally environments
with ml2 or v2 plugin.

Closes-Bug: #1650255

Change-Id: I99b09597e7f95c19708a52dfbd003c88c8f28cb9
Signed-off-by: Antonio Ojea <aojea@midokura.com>

commit_message:
RAX partprobe fix

RAX seems to have an issue where partprobe fails. This change
has partprobe executed only on the loopback devices rather then
rescan everything.

Change-Id: Ic3b75d234d0333ef000a826fc22eacb2cda8465a

Failing test (mac osx) - test_cache_ephemeral

Test test_cache_ephemeral fails on mac osx with the following traceback.

      File "mock/mock.py", line 1305, in patched
        return func(*args, **keywargs)
      File "test_imagebackend.py", line 773, in test_cache_ephemeral
        ephemeral_size=size_gb, size=size)
      File "imagebackend.py", line 206, in cache
        fileutils.ensure_tree(base_dir)
      File "oslo_utils/fileutils.py", line 40, in ensure_tree
        os.makedirs(path, mode)
      File "python2.7/os.py", line 150, in makedirs
        makedirs(head, mode)
    OSError: [Errno 21] Is a directory: '/'

Change-Id: I695ccae534d2f53fdace3f7bb4bc1df953d712d3

commit_message:
Block 3.1 message with c-sch RPCAPI pinned to 3.0

notify_service_capabilities was sent unconditionally, even when we
shouldn't allow it due to RPC version pinning. This commit blocks that
message when RPC API is pinned to anything lower than 3.1.

Change-Id: Ib2e4f65f626cad79773f46077a75813f434cb806
Closes-Bug: 1647789

commit_message:
add --missing-milestone flag to list-deliverables

This argument can be used to query for cycle-with-milestones
deliverables that have not yet tagged a specific milestone.

Also fix a bug in the logic for determining the latest release.

Change-Id: Ibe71cdd60e5ccdd03cec3bc7148c2bafc2bf2c5a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
WIP: Test to prevent hanging of job

Dstat doesn't exit in the end of the job and after postci function
finished it still runs and hangs job.

Change-Id: I31a49006b8c8065b15812908f7251d22cb1661f4

commit_message:
Revert "[Manila] Make grenade job voting"

This reverts commit c9aa2bc93cc5c99ee403b2f8afc965720b42986f.
Because job has been broken by [1] and fix is not
merged yet [2]. It will unblock possibility to merge
changes to manila project.

[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/411768/

Change-Id: I5d70dcabff416c6947fe11b18997b76ec05cf86e

commit_message:
modify useless assertions.

the origin one is always true and useless.
the result of 'type(a is b)' is <type 'bool'>, 
and "assertTrue(<type 'bool'>) is always true whatever 'a is b' is true
or false.

'tox -epy27' commands succeeded in my environment.

Change-Id: I452c1a65b63ba773065e8d19676ed64021fa49dc

commit_message:
Set tasks fail_on_error to false for noop run

Add an option to transaction context that the
run is 'noop'. Ask tasks serializers to set fail_on_error to false
depending on whether we are are running in noop or not noop mode

Change-Id: I4bcc133aaf22a8a4d7ab3c12d708034d4c9e91cd
Closes-bug: #1626067

commit_message:
fix tarball-base values for newton and ocata

Several deliverables are linking to the wrong place, resulting in 404
errors. Fix that by updating the tarball-base values for projects where
the dist name and the deliverable name do not match.

Change-Id: I4e3c2e040b312ef42661c8a2d413281ec09de869
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
add validation rule to check tarball-base

We don't want to take the time to check out all of the source code for
all projects during the documentation build, so add a validation step to
check that the deliverable being modified has the tarball-base value set
properly, if it needs to be overridden from the default.

Change-Id: Id39bdd1e0a9fe771b78a053ba73803c3c095f135
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/89/411989/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from openstack_releases import pythonutilsdef validate_tarball_base(deliverable_info, workdir, mk_warning, mk_error): """Check the tarball-base value against the sdist name. Ensure that the tarball-base value for the deliverable matches the project. This assumes only one repository if the deliverable name does not match the dist name. """ if not deliverable_info.get('releases'): return please = ('It is too expensive to determine this value during ' 'the site build, please set it explicitly.') final_release = deliverable_info['releases'][-1] for project in final_release['projects']: gitutils.clone_repo(workdir, project['repo']) sdist = pythonutils.get_sdist_name(workdir, project['repo']) expected = deliverable_info.get( 'tarball-base', os.path.basename(project['repo']), ) if sdist == expected: continue if 'tarball-base' in deliverable_info: mk_error( ('tarball-base for %s is set to %r ' 'but the sdist name is actually %r. ' + please) % ( project['repo'], expected, sdist)) else: mk_error( ('tarball-base for %s defaults to %r ' 'but the sdist name is actually %r. ' + please) % ( project['repo'], expected, sdist)) validate_tarball_base(deliverable_info, workdir, mk_warning, mk_error)

commit_message:
teach missing-releases to look for artifacts as well as tags

We need a tool to verify that the release artifacts exist on the
tarballs site. The missing-releases command was already looking for
missing tags, so have it look for the tarballs, too.

This change refactors the URL generation code into a separate module so
it can be used by missing-releases and the sphinx extension. It also
creates a reusable function for testing a link, and has the gitutils
module functions responsible for looking for tags, branches, etc. use
it.

Change the default behavior to only look at the most recent release for
each deliverable, and add an option to go back to the previous behavior
of scanning all of them.

Change-Id: Ic7345466ccd83cf2d8d9d6d019107d6fbba171cc
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/30/411530/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from openstack_releases import links filenames = sorted(glob.glob('deliverables/%s/*.yaml' % args.series)) else: filenames = sorted(gitutils.find_modified_deliverable_files()) link_mode = deliverable_info.get('artifact-link-mode', 'tarball') print('tag:found', end=' ') else: print('tag:MISSING', end=' ') errors.append('%s missing tag %s' % (project['repo'], release['version'])) # Look for the tarball associated with the tag and # report if that exists. if link_mode == 'tarball': url = links.tarball_url(release['version'], project) if links.link_exists(url): print('tarball:found') else: print('tarball:MISSING\n%s' % url) errors.append('%s missing tarball %s' % (filename, url))
deleted_lines: filenames = glob.glob('deliverables/%s/*.yaml' % args.series) else: filenames = gitutils.find_modified_deliverable_files() print('found') else: print('MISSING') errors.append( '%s missing tag %s' % ( project['repo'], release['version'], ) )

commit_message:
Release octavia 0.8.1

Resolves issues with building and using amphora images.
This release also includes using a network namespace inside the
amphora.

Change-Id: Iee1a4881beb89a71e3a1db70654ed32f2194d637

commit_message:
Fix DHCP Port Creation on Service Subnets

This changes the IPAM logic for service subnets to allow DHCP ports
to be created on subnets of any service type, provided that the subnet
has DHCP enabled.. This ensures that DHCP ports can still be created
automatically on 'nova:compute' service subnets, for example.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I736262f2a7d3f3d7dfdc5276e2364aca7187d18b
Closes-Bug: #1636963

############################################################################### ########## Testing gate job ########## ############################################################################### export PYTHONUNBUFFERED=true export DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST=1 export DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_NOTESTS=1 export BRANCH_OVERRIDE={branch-override} if [ "$BRANCH_OVERRIDE" != "default" ] ; then export OVERRIDE_ZUUL_BRANCH=$BRANCH_OVERRIDE fi export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG="CINDER_ENABLED_BACKENDS={backends}" REPO_URL=https://git.openstack.org/openstack/ export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'
'"enable_plugin devstack-plugin-nfs $REPO_URL/devstack-plugin-nfs" export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'
'"ENABLE_NFS_CINDER=True" export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'
'"enable_plugin devstack-plugin-glusterfs $REPO_URL/devstack-plugin-glusterfs" export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'
'"CONFIGURE_GLUSTERFS_CINDER=True" export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'
'"enable_plugin devstack-plugin-ceph $REPO_URL/devstack-plugin-ceph" export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'
'"enable_plugin devstack-plugin-bdd $REPO_URL/devstack-plugin-bdd" export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG+=$'
'"enable_plugin drbd-devstack $REPO_URL/drbd-devstack" function post_test_hook {{ /opt/stack/new/cinder/tools/hooks/run_multi_backend_matrix.sh }} export -f post_test_hook ############################################################################### ###############################################################################

commit_message:
Remove agent vendor passthru completely

This patch removes all the basic classes for lookup/heartbeat as vendor
passthru from Ironic code, as well as removes those API endpoints from
list of API public routes.

It also removes the agent vendor passthru from fake drivers.

Change-Id: Ia133a63ed4e8ed99551f6d2656d24e990300f3a2
Closes-Bug: #1640533

commit_message:
Add description filed to ports - DB

We can save some ports connectivity information which is useful
for operators, like the position of the port in server, and in
the LACP group with which port.

Change-Id: I611d6e92ea447e8cb41e4a9787487778a1a7dae3
Partial-bug: #1534893

commit_message:
too many digits after the decimal point

'global_efficacy' field print too many digits
 after the decimal point.
 for example 14.2857142857 %
 two digits are enough
 for example 14.29%

Closes-Bug: #1650159

Change-Id: I4af3ef5b250d7e0b921269cc91ec46978d090c10

commit_message:
Use the device hints matching mechanism from ironic-lib

This patch is replacing the ironic-inspector own implementation for
validating the root device hints in favor of the standard one from
ironic-lib.

The implementation in ironic-lib is flexible enough and fits in
ironic-inspector well so no big updates to functional or unittests
are needed.

A new dependency for ironic-lib was added to requirements.txt.

Change-Id: I0f2b8f463232d0d5b42d0b6e343d5c6e336d32c7
Closes-Bug: #1648133
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/52/408552/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ironic_lib import utils as il_utils try: device = il_utils.match_root_device_hints(inventory['disks'], hints) except (TypeError, ValueError): raise utils.Error(_('Invalid root device size hint, expected ' 'an integer, got %s') % hints['size'], if not device: raise utils.Error(_('No disks satisfied root device hints'), node_info=node_info, data=introspection_data) LOG.debug('Disk %(disk)s of size %(size)s satisfies ' 'root device hints', {'disk': device.get('name'), 'size': device['size']}, node_info=node_info, data=introspection_data) introspection_data['root_disk'] = device
deleted_lines: if 'size' in hints: # Special case to match IPA behaviour try: hints['size'] = int(hints['size']) except (TypeError, ValueError): raise utils.Error(_('Invalid root device size hint, expected ' 'an integer, got %s') % hints['size'], node_info=node_info, data=introspection_data) for disk in inventory['disks']: properties = disk.copy() # Root device hints are in GiB, data from IPA is in bytes properties['size'] //= units.Gi for name, value in hints.items(): actual = properties.get(name) if actual != value: LOG.debug('Disk %(disk)s does not satisfy hint ' '%(name)s=%(value)s, actual value is %(actual)s', {'disk': disk.get('name'), 'name': name, 'value': value, 'actual': actual}, break else: LOG.debug('Disk %(disk)s of size %(size)s satisfies ' 'root device hints', {'disk': disk.get('name'), 'size': disk['size']}, node_info=node_info, data=introspection_data) introspection_data['root_disk'] = disk return raise utils.Error(_('No disks satisfied root device hints'), node_info=node_info, data=introspection_data)

commit_message:
Delete conntrack when remote ipset member removed

Through [1] ipset members are updated in update_security_group_members
instead of updating during firewall apply. In the same way, we will
delete conntrack entries immediately after deleting remote ipset
members(in update_security_group_members) instead of deleting them after
firewall apply.

As explained in [2], this change partially fixes bug #1580377 i.e it
deletes conntrack entries on remote hosts for a removed port.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/347068/
[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1580377/comments/13

Co-Authored-By:shihanzhang <shihanzhang@huawei.com>
Partial-Bug: #1580377
Change-Id: Iea3344a24e2a068b794c44796b4c945432379c13
(cherry picked from commit 9168dbf93d70ec4df6ab29d2b300497fef401682)

commit_message:
Add version pin for image related function

image functions deprecated after v2.35 but we didn't pin the
version for them, so when use 2.37 by default won't work.

Change-Id: I450917f7fcbfe0a3ea7921c82af9863e80cb40a1
Closes-Bug: 1638506

added_lines: def deprecated_image(fn): @functools.wraps(fn) def wrapped(cs, *args, **kwargs): command_name = '-'.join(fn.__name__.split('_')[1:]) print('WARNING: Command %s is deprecated and will be removed ' 'after Nova 15.0.0 is released. Use python-glanceclient ' 'or python-openstackclient instead.' % command_name, file=sys.stderr) # The image proxy API methods were deprecated in 2.36 and will return # a 404 so we fallback to 2.35 to maintain a transition for CLI users. want_version = api_versions.APIVersion('2.35') cur_version = cs.api_version if cs.api_version > want_version: cs.api_version = want_version try: return fn(cs, *args, **kwargs) finally: cs.api_version = cur_version wrapped.__doc__ = 'DEPRECATED: ' + fn.__doc__ return wrapped @deprecated_image@deprecated_image@deprecated_image@deprecated_image

Use python-glanceclient or openstackclient ' 'instead.' % command_name, file=sys.stderr) emit_image_deprecation_warning('image-list') emit_image_deprecation_warning('image-meta') emit_image_deprecation_warning('image-show') emit_image_deprecation_warning('image-delete')

commit_message:
Unconditionally setup cells v2 when upgrading from newton

With nova change I72fb724dc13e1a5f4e97c58915b538ba761c582d you
are required to have setup the cell0 database and run the
simple_cell_setup command.

This is needed for the devstack change that changes the
default value of NOVA_CONFIGURE_CELLSV2 to True.

If1af9c478e8ea2420f2523a9bb8b70fafddc86b7

Change-Id: Ie44e615384df464516aa30b9044b5e54b7d995bb

commit_message:
Adds basic internationalization support

This patch adds an I18NProvider component to implement react-intl's
translation mechanisms and replaces text strings in the deployment_plan
components with formatted messages.

The patch also contains scripts to convert extracted messages to `.pot`
files (which can be used with zanata.org) and back. See more details in
the README changes.

More components need to be updated once this patch has landed.

Change-Id: Ida9fc65c65bedf377341220be1d7225d1ae58b2c
Implements: blueprint tripleo-ui-i18n-support-for-js

commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I4eab4811390a8d98e15f0dea1a7b381e16ad2d66

commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems(iter) with iter.items()

As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using six.iteritems(iter) to
achieve iterators. We can use iter.items() instead, as it will
return iterators in PY3 as well.

[1]http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I7ee63fd6d0dcce1162cd96ca2935ad75b751c876
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-dashboard refs/changes/08/412308/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for name, label in labels.items(): for name, item in data.items(): for item, item_value in context.items():
deleted_lines: for name, label in six.iteritems(labels): for name, item in six.iteritems(data): for item, item_value in six.iteritems(context):

commit_message:
Remove /usr/bin/install from allowed commands

This essentially allows the user to copy any files and set any
ownership on any files. Can be used to do anything on the system and
all users in 'kolla' group have access to it.

Change-Id: I9d6cd2b4ca40cb536484fa45e80692105b5fa2a4

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 13.3.11

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available stable
SHA's, copies the release notes from the updated roles into the
integrated repo, updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's, and
updates the appropriate python requirements pins.

Change-Id: If9f512cad02f223bcb71f2ad3db647f7ba663658
Depends-On: Ie36e1e457c76ae69b31d7be12e54e1befbd482a8

commit_message:
Mark Hitachi VSP volume drivers as unsupported

The Hitachi VSP CI has not reported past our CI requirements.

Checking name: Hitachi VSP CI
query: 'https://review.openstack.org/changes/?q=reviewer:"Hitachi VSP CI" AND project:"openstack/cinder"&o=MESSAGES&o=DETAILED_ACCOUNTS' failed with:
User Hitachi VSP CI not found

Per Cinder's non-compliance policy [1] this patch marks the driver
as unsupported and deprecated and it will be approved if the issue
is not corrected by the next cycle.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Cinder/tested-3rdParty-drivers#Non-Compliance_Policy

Change-Id: I10cf1919f20633a8587ca4f0805428f51c00ef7d

commit_message:
Replaces uuid.uuid4 with uuidutils.generate_uuid()

Openstack common has a wrapper for generating uuids.We should
use that function when generating uuids for consistency.

Change-Id: I8768b6c665329163cb87dc69c9fa022bdee1b65d
Closes-Bug: #1082248

commit_message:
test_service_providers: require service-type ext

test_service_providers assumes that service-type api extension.
So skip it when it's not enabled.

Change-Id: I22a3f184b24b674bd085af455ef074932b742442
Closes-bug: #1650351

commit_message:
Run stack/test-config phase for tempest plugin conf

Devstack plugins contain `test-config` phase, called at the end of
devstack to configure tempest environment, and installing target setup
w/o plugin tempest conf may lead to misconfiguration.

Change-Id: I5575ba9128cfb2887c85fe634d59bb19f121efc9

commit_message:
Remove white space between print () in plan_management.py

There is a white space in line [print (*,
then we remove it.

This change is being backported to fix pep8 failures in stable/newton
which are blocking bug backports.

Change-Id: I66ae2b1654f08f1518f0297c13588d01ed80fbb9
(cherry picked from commit 3baf0f6f06b924c8f12c87f76ab157b0f9a8b2fa)

commit_message:
Use assertGreater(len(x), y) instead of assertTrue(len(x) > y)

assertGreater provides a nicer error message if it fails.

Change-Id: I37da4d5cb6d41ab7fdef4900862352dbc498f433

subject: Set rabbitmq's port and IP via the config file and not the env file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-14 12:07:19.000000000', 'files': ['puppet/services/rabbitmq.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/de923539c81979380ba0b94b757c09e8bba9d158', 'message': "Set rabbitmq's port and IP via the config file and not the env file

The RabbitMQ's puppet manifest configures the node's IP and port through
environment variables. While this would usually be fine, it doesn't
allow us to use TLS-only, since it will always try to start a TCP
listener. So, by setting these values through the config file, when
setting ssl_only for rabbitmq, they will effectively be discarded and
thus allow us to use an SSL listener on the same port.

Change-Id: I33d051a8c740baf69b99517378e1f9b0f3cc1681
"}]
commit_message:
Set rabbitmq's port and IP via the config file and not the env file

The RabbitMQ's puppet manifest configures the node's IP and port through
environment variables. While this would usually be fine, it doesn't
allow us to use TLS-only, since it will always try to start a TCP
listener. So, by setting these values through the config file, when
setting ssl_only for rabbitmq, they will effectively be discarded and
thus allow us to use an SSL listener on the same port.

Change-Id: I33d051a8c740baf69b99517378e1f9b0f3cc1681
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/22/410722/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NODE_PORT: '' NODE_IP_ADDRESS: '' rabbitmq::interface: {get_param: [ServiceNetMap, RabbitmqNetwork]}

experimental job to test this use-case. Once the job is stable, we'll
move it to the gate.
